question: On þissum geare ferde seo (micel) #### scipfierd eft on Englalande - In this year the great navy went again to England
explanation: Here 'micel' is modifying the singular nominative feminine 'scipfierd' so it takes the feminine 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'seo', 'scipfierd' is feminine so 'micel' should take the feminine nominative 'e' ending

question: Se (yfel) #### unrihtwisa cyning spræc mid his yflan tungan - The evil unrighteous king spoke with his evil mouth
explanation: Here 'yfel' is modifying the singular nominative masculine 'cyning' so it takes the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'se', 'cyning' is masculine so 'yfel' should take the masculine nominative 'a' ending

question: Se (swet) #### mete ðe hie heton monna se him cuom of hefonum - The sweet meats that they call mana which comes from heaven
explanation: Here 'swet' is modifying the singular nominative masculine 'mete' so it takes the 'a' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'se', 'mete' is masculine so 'swet' should take the masculine nominative 'a' ending

question: Dol bið þæt (lytel) #### scip ðe gæð on deop wæter - Foolish is the little ship that goes in deep water
explanation: Here 'lytel' is modifying the singular nominative neuter 'scip' so it takes the neuter 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'lytel' becomes 'lytle' when it gains the singular nominative neuter suffix 'e'

question: On þissum geare sende he þone (eald) #### biscop Wulfstan to þæm stede þe wæs genemned Readingum - In this year he sent the old bishop to the place that was called Reading
explanation: Here 'eald' is modifying the singular accusative masculine 'biscop' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: He sende þæt (halig) #### lic to þæm mynster - He sent the holy body to the minster
explanation: Here 'halig' is modifying the singular accusative neuter 'lic' so it takes the 'e' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: An adjective takes the gender of its noun. As can be seen by 'þæt', 'lic' is neuter so 'halig' should take the neuter accusative 'e' ending

While the suffix is correct, adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'halig' becomes 'halge' when it gains the singular accusative neuter suffix 'e'

question: Se ðe gebigde ðone (heah) #### heofonlican bigels - He who bowed the high vault of heaven
explanation: Here 'heah' is modifying the singular accusative masculine 'bigels' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Words ending in 'h' replace their 'h' with a 'g' before a suffix beginning with a vowel, so 'heah' becomes 'heagan' when it gains the ending 'an'

question: Se deofol gesette hine uppan ðam scylfe ðæs (heah) #### temples - The devil set him upon the summit of the high temple
explanation: Here 'heah' is modifying the singular genitive masculine 'temple' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: Words ending in 'h' replace their 'h' with a 'g' before a suffix beginning with a vowel, so 'heah' becomes 'heagan' when it gains the ending 'an'

question: He is in ðone deopan grund ðæs hatan leges and ðæs (heard) #### leges - He is in the deep abyss of the hot flame and the hard flame
explanation: Here 'heard' is modifying the singular genitive masculine 'leg' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Hwæt synt nu þæs foremeran ond þæs (wis) #### goldsmiðes ban Welondes? - What now are the bones of that renowned and wise goldsmith Weland?
explanation: Here 'wis' is modifying the singular genitive masculine 'goldsmiðes' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ða wicingas eodon þa to þære (lytel) #### iege þe is genemned Iona - The vikings then went to the little island that is named Iona
explanation: Here 'lytel' is modifying the singular dative feminine 'ieg' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: While the suffix is correct, adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'lytel' becomes 'lytlan' when it gains the singular genitive feminine suffix 'an'

question: Woroldlicra weorca on ðam (halig) #### dæge geswice man georne - On that holy day, let men abstain from worldly works
explanation: Here 'halig' is modifying the singular dative masculine 'dæg' so it takes the 'an' ending

commonMistakes.explanation: While the suffix is correct, adjectives with two syllables lose the vowel of the second syllable when they gain a suffix, so 'halig' becomes 'halgan' when it gains the singular dative masculine suffix 'an'

question: Ic ðe hæbbe aþriet mid ðis (lang) #### spelle - I have bored you with this long speech
explanation: Here 'lang' is modifying the singular dative neuter 'spell' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ac uton don swa swa God tæhte þæt ure (<em>god</em) #### weorc beon on ða wisan mannum cuðe - But let us do as God has taught, that our good works may be so known to men
explanation: Here 'god' is modifying the plural nominative neuter 'weorc' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ða (heard) #### þrowunga ðe he adreag - The hard sufferings than he endured
explanation: Here 'heard' is modifying the plural nominative feminine 'þrowunga' so it takes the 'an' ending

question: Ða (eald) #### wunde spræce þa ealdan race - The old wounds speak the old stories
explanation: Here 'eald' is modifying the plural nominative feminine 'racu' so it takes the 'an' suffix

question: (eald) #### wif scielde þæt bearn mid hire lice - An old woman shielded the child with her body
explanation: Here 'eald' is modifying the singular nominative neuter 'wif' so it takes no suffix

question: Lucia to manegum witum geworht be (yfel) #### man - Lucia was put to many tortures by an evil man
explanation: Here 'yfel' is modifying the singular nominative masculine 'man' so it takes no suffix

question: (halig) #### abbod nerede ða hæðenan cyningas - A holy bishop saved the heathen kings
explanation: Here 'halig' is modifying the singular nominative masculine 'man' so it takes no suffix

question: On Æþelredes cyninges dagum, timbrode seo fierd (micel) #### mynster - In King Ethelred's day, the army built a great monastery
explanation: Here 'micel' is modifying the singular accusative neuter 'mynster' so it takes no suffix

question: Harold cyning þis gehierde þa gaderode he (micel) #### fierd - King Harold heard this, then he gathered a large army
explanation: Here 'micel' is modifying the singular accusative feminine 'fierd' so it takes the 'e' suffix

question: Se cnapa huntode (æðele) #### hwæl - The boy hunts a noble whale
explanation: Here 'æðele' is modifying the singular accusative masculine 'hwæl' so it takes the 'ne' suffix

question: She wæs (æðele) #### gebyrde - She was of noble birth
explanation: Here 'æðele' is modifying the singular genitive feminine 'byrd' so it takes the 're' suffix

question: Buteran ond beana ond ealle clæne þingc ic ete mid (micel) #### þancunge - Butter and beans and all clean things I eat with many thanks
explanation: Here 'micel' is modifying the singular genitive feminine 'þancung' so it takes the 're' suffix

question: Ic fliemde þa wealas to (weste) #### iege - I expelled the foreigners to a deserted island
explanation: Here 'weste' is modifying the singular dative feminine 'ieg' so it takes the 're' suffix

question: Ic hafu gecnawen on (heard) #### hyge ðæt ðu hælend eart middangeardes - I have acknowledged in my hard heart that you are saviour of the world
explanation: Here 'heard' is modifying the singular dative masculine 'hyge' so it takes the 'um' suffix

question: We rædaþ ond hieraþ word be Æþelrede cyning, be (eald) #### weale, and be þæm gefeohtum - We read and hear words about King Ethelred, about old wealth and about the fights
explanation: Here 'eald' is modifying the singular dative masculine 'weala' so it takes the 'um' suffix

question: (wis) #### men onfeng þone anhaga - Wise men received the wanderer
explanation: Here 'wis' is modifying the plural nominative masculine 'man' so it takes the 'e' suffix

question: (geong) #### preostas mette þæs cyninges bearn - Young priests met the king's children
explanation: Here 'geong' is modifying the plural nominative masculine 'preost' so it takes the 'e' suffix

question: (god) #### sawla sint undeaþlice and ece - Good souls are immortal and eternal
explanation: Here 'god' is modifying the plural nominative feminine 'sawel' so it takes the 'a' suffix

question: Næs þes þegn þa unwise þa he sende (eald) #### scipu to þa wealum - Is this thane not then unwise when he sent old ships to the foreigners
explanation: Here 'eald' is modifying the plural accusative neuter 'scip' so it takes the 'e' suffix

question: Se abbod wæs eald, ac he lærde (geong) #### preostas mid wisum wordum - The abbod was old but he instructed young priests with wise words
explanation: Here 'geong' is modifying the plural accusative masculine 'preost' so it takes the 'e' suffix

question: Ælfred cyning gefeaht wið feower sciphlæstas (Denisc) #### monna here - King Alfred fought with four crews of Danish men here
explanation: Here 'Denisc' is modifying the plural genitive masculine 'man' so it takes the 'ra' suffix

question: Wæs he swiðe æþelra gebyrda ond (god) #### - He was of very noble and good birth
explanation: Here 'god' is modifying the plural genitive feminine 'byrd' so it takes the 'ra' suffix

question: Win nys drenc cilda ac ealdra ond (wis) #### men- Wine is not a drink of children, but of old and wise men
explanation: Here 'wis' is modifying the plural genitive masculine 'man' so it takes the 'ra' suffix

question: On ælcum þingum ðe ðær unbecweden biþ on bocum and on swylcum (lytel) #### þingum - On all things that are unbequeathed, books and other such little things
explanation: Here 'lytel' is modifying the plural dative neuter 'þing' so it takes the 'um' suffix

question: Dunstan wæs unwise and he befæstte þæt land to (geong) #### preostum - Dunstan was unwise and he commited that land to young priests
explanation: Here 'geong' is modifying the plural dative masculine 'preost' so it takes the 'um' suffix

question: Hie eodon fram Norwege mid (micel) #### scipfierde - They came from Norway with a large navy
explanation: Here 'micel' is modifying the plural dative feminine 'scipfierd' so it takes the 'um' suffix

question: He is (strang) #### ðonne ic - He is stronger than I
explanation: The stem of 'strang' undergoes i-mutation to become 'streng', but it isn't modifying a noun so it takes the 'ra' suffix to become 'strengra'

commonMistakes.explanation: Comparatives only decline if the noun they are modifying a noun. This adjective is not modifying a noun, so it becomes 'strengra'
The stem of 'strang' undergoes 'i-mutation' so the 'a' becomes 'e', meaning 'strang' becomes 'strengra' in the comparative

question: Bebead he ðæt him mon (lang) #### cwidas beforan cwæde, and he symle gedefelice æftercwæþ - He ordered longer sayings to be spoken before him, and he always repeated them properly
explanation: The stem of 'lang' undergoes i-mutation to become 'leng', and it takes the 'ran' suffix to become 'lengran' as comparatives decline weak if they are modifying a noun

commonMistakes.explanation: The stem of 'lang' undergoes 'i-mutation' so the 'a' becomes 'e', meaning 'lang' becomes 'lengran' in the comparative
Here 'lang' takes the 'ran' suffix to become 'lengran' as comparatives decline weak if they are modifying a noun
The stem of 'lang' undergoes i-mutation to become 'leng', and it takes the 'ran' suffix to become 'lengran' as comparatives decline weak if they are modifying a noun

question: Ic in wite sceal bidan in bendum ond me (god) #### ham for oferhygdum æfre ne wene - I must in tormen abide in bonds, and never hope for any better home for my pride
explanation: The adjective 'god' is irregular and so becomes 'beteran' in the comparative when modifying a noun

question: Se horshwæl biþ micle (lytel) #### ðonne oðre hwalas - The walrus is much smaller than other whales
explanation: The adjective 'lytel' is irregular and so becomes 'læssa' in the comparative when not modifying a noun

question: Ic towurpe mine bernu and ic wyrce (micel) #### bernu - I will tear down my barns and I will build bigger barns
explanation: The adjective 'micel' is irregular and so becomes 'maran' in the comparative when modifying a noun

question: Ðæt læstede þa xix wintra þa hwile þe Stephne cyning wæs one æfre hit wæs (yfel) #### ond wiersa - That lasted 19 winters while Stephen was king and ever it was worse and worse
explanation: The adjective 'yfel' is irregular and so becomes 'wiersa' in the comparative as it is not modifying a noun

question: Næfre he ær ne siððan (heard) #### hæle fand - Never before or since did he find a stouter warrior
explanation: Here 'heard' takes the 'ran' suffix as it is modifying the noun 'hæle'

question: Wisa, hwilc cræft þe geþuht betwux þas (furðre) #### wesan - Teacher, which craft do you think is the greater?
explanation: Here 'furðre' loses its 're' and takes the 'ra' suffix to become 'furðra', as it is not modifying a noun

question: Se wudu is eastlang and westlang hund twelftiges mila lang oððe (lang) #### - The wood, from east to west, is twelve hundred miles long or longer
explanation: The stem of 'lang' undergoes i-mutation to become 'leng', and it takes the 'ra' suffix to become 'lengra', as it is not directly modifying a noun

question: Ðam (mild) #### cyninge Wihtræde rixigendum - In the reign of the kindest king Wihtræd
explanation: Here 'mild' takes the superlative suffix 'ost' and the weak suffix 'an', as it comes after the definitive article 'þam'

question: Se lichoma ðonne on ðone (heard) #### stenc and on ðone fulostan biþ gecyrred - The body then shall be turned to the strongest and foulest stench
explanation: Here 'heard' takes the superlative suffix 'ost' and the weak suffix 'an', as it comes after the definitive article 'ðone'

question: Cwædon ðæt he wære manna (mild) #### and monþwærost - They said that he was kindest and most courteous of men
explanation: Here 'heard' takes the superlative suffix 'ost' and no suffix

question: He sohte fram ðam ieldestan oþ ðone (geong) #### - He searched from the eldest to the youngest
explanation: The stem of 'geong' undergoes i-mutation to become 'ging', and takes the superlative suffix 'est' and the weak suffix 'an', as it comes after the demonstrative pronoun 'ðone'

question: Ic gyrne fultum ðinre foreþingrædene ðu (halig) #### mægden and þrowystr - I earnestly impolore your help, you holiest maiden and martyr
explanation: Here 'halig' takes the superlative suffix 'ost' and the strong accusative feminine suffix 'e' as it is modifying 'mægden'

question: Se wæs on lare and on dæde se (heah) #### - He was in learning and in deed the highest
explanation: The stem of 'heah' undergoes i-mutation to become 'hieh', and takes the superlative suffix 'st' and the weak nominative masculine suffix 'a', as it comes after the demonstrative pronoun 'se'

commonMistakes.explanation: Because 'heah' ends in a 'h', it drops the vowel in 'ost' to take the superlative suffix 'st'. Since it modifies a weak nominative masculine noun, it also takes the suffix 'a'

question: He me sealde ðæt (god) #### hors - He gave me the best horse
explanation: The adjective 'god' is irregular, becoming 'betest' in the superlative. It takes no suffix because 'hors' is neuter and neuter accusative nouns have no suffix

question: Sceall beon se (lytel) #### dæl nyhst þæm tune ðe se deada man on lið - The smallest portion shall be closest to where the dead man lies
explanation: The adjective 'lytel' is irregular, becoming 'læst' in the superlative. It takes the weak nominative masculine ending 'a' to become 'læsta', as it comes after the demonstrative pronoun 'se'

question: Hit is ealra wyrta (micel) #### - It is greatest of all herbs
explanation: The adjective 'micel' is irregular, becoming 'mæst' in the superlative. It takes no suffix

question: Se deofol sloh lob mid ðære (yfel) #### wunde - The devil slew Job with the worst of wounds
explanation: The adjective 'yfel' is irregular, becoming 'wierst' in the superlative. It takes the weak genitive feminine ending 'an' to become 'wierstan'
